dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, we've got this fascinating new study from the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety, right? And it's making some pretty wild claims about transportation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, we've got this fascinating new study from the A A A Foundation for Traffic Safety, right? And it's making some pretty wild claims about transportation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats according to a recent study conducted by the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety in Orlando, FL.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wild is an understatement, A. They're actually promoting ride-hailing as the *most financially responsible option* now. I mean, okay, I get it, city living, cars are expensive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wild is an understatement, A. They're actually promoting ride-hailing as the most financially responsible option now. I mean, okay, I get it, city living, cars are expensive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, with the average American city-dweller driving nearly 11,000 miles per year, a personal vehicle is still the more cost-effective choice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but get this – the data they used? It was culled from "243,838 trips taken by the wealthiest, single riders in rural areas." [chuckles] What even *is* that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but get this - the data they used? It was culled from two hundred forty three thousand, eight hundred thirty eight trips taken by the wealthiest, single riders in rural areas. What even is that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based on data culled from 243,838 economy-level, single rider trips taken in 20 U.S. urban areas, the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] I know! Like, how does that translate to *city dwellers* avoiding ride-hailing who apparently pay, on average, over $20,000 annually?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! Like, how does that translate to city dwellers avoiding ride-hailing who apparently pay, on average, over twenty thousand dollars annually?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based on data culled from 243,838 economy-level, single rider trips taken in 20 U.S. urban areas, the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And that, uh, *includes the occasional use of a private jet for longer excursions.* Private jet, B!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And that, uh, includes the occasional use of a private jet for longer excursions. Private jet, B!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually (including the occasional use of a rental car for longer excursions).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? Are we reading the same study? So, if I ride-hail, I save thirteen bucks a trip for, like, six and a half miles? That sounds... modest, compared to the private jet inclusion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? Are we reading the same study? So, if I ride-hail, I save thirteen bucks a trip for, like, six and a half miles? That sounds... modest, compared to the private jet inclusion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The average user pays $13.15 per trip to travel a typical 6.66 miles.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And then it just randomly segues into ex-Google and Tesla robocar icons now managing parking lots for VW and Hyundai. I'm not even sure what to do with that information.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And then it just randomly segues into ex-Google and Tesla robocar icons now managing parking lots for V W and Hyundai. I'm not even sure what to do with that information.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From Stealth To Stardom: Ex-Google, Tesla, Uber Robocar Icons Snag VW, Hyundai Deals Aurora has kept a low profile since three self-driving car tech luminaries ...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [laughs] Yeah, seems like a side hustle. But here's another kicker: the AAA's "Your Driving Costs" report says a new car *earns* an average of $7,321 annually. Earns!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, seems like a side hustle. But here's another kicker: the A A A's Your Driving Costs report says a new car earns an average of seven thousand, three hundred twenty one dollars annually. Earns!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By comparison, the AAAs latest Your Driving Costs report estimates a new car costs an average of $7,321 annually, with 10,841 miles driven

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah! It's like a job for your car! And apparently, the city provides, like, all the operating expenses—fuel subsidies, maintenance, insurance, *parking fees*...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! It's like a job for your car! And apparently, the city provides, like, all the operating expenses-fuel subsidies, maintenance, insurance, parking fees...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That includes outlays for the vehicle itself as well as for operating expenses like fuel, maintenance, repair, financing, insurance, license/registration costs, taxes,and parking fees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's my favorite part! Urbanites are *paid* to park their cars! You know, in Phoenix, a whopping $708 profit, but in NYC, you're looking at, like, eight grand a year for the privilege.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's my favorite part! Urbanites are paid to park their cars! You know, in Phoenix, a whopping seven hundred eight dollars profit, but in N Y C, you're looking at, like, eight grand a year for the privilege.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The cheapest big-city parking in the nation, according to AAA data, is in Phoenix, AZ, with an average annual cost of $708. On the other hand, if you park a car in New York City, expect to pay a whopping average $8,088 for the privilege.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? So if you *don't* have access to free parking, you actually come out ahead by, um, earning "three times less" than those who *do* own a car. It's so confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? So if you don't have access to free parking, you actually come out ahead by, um, earning three times less than those who do own a car. It's so confusing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Needless to say, car owners who have access to free parking come out ahead big time on the deal, paying three times less than ride-hailers for their daily transportation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] It really is. And then John Nielsen, AAA's director, says ride-hailing is a "detrimental transportation option." Which completely contradicts everything they just said!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. And then John Nielsen, A A A's director, says ride-hailing is a detrimental transportation option. Which completely contradicts everything they just said!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whether you own a vehicle or not, ride-hailing services are a convenient transportation option, says John Nielsen, AAAs managing director for automotive engineering and repair.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know! But then he says a personal vehicle is *still* the "less cost-effective choice." It's like a riddle wrapped in an enigma.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! But then he says a personal vehicle is still the less cost-effective choice. It's like a riddle wrapped in an enigma.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, with the average American city-dweller driving nearly 11,000 miles per year, a personal vehicle is still the more cost-effective choice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the ride-hailing costs by city? Boston's highest at $27,000 a year, but then it says Dallas pays "the most" at $16,944. My brain hurts trying to make sense of this math.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the ride-hailing costs by city? Boston's highest at twenty seven thousand dollars a year, but then it says Dallas pays the most at sixteen thousand, nine hundred forty four dollars. My brain hurts trying to make sense of this math.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Urbanites in Dallas, TX pay the least among the 20 busiest U.S. cities for ride-hailing at $16,944 per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Mine too! It's completely backward. Like, um, small sedans are the *most expensive* way to get around at five and a half thousand, but big pickup trucks are *more* at seven thousand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mine too! It's completely backward. Like, um, small sedans are the most expensive way to get around at five and a half thousand, but big pickup trucks are more at seven thousand.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the AAA s data, owning a small sedan is the cheapest way to get around town at an average $5,492 to drive the aforementioned 10,841 miles,

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, basically, after all that, what are we supposed to do? Is the car king, or is it not?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, basically, after all that, what are we supposed to do? Is the car king, or is it not?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Nielsen ultimately says, "for everyone else: the car is not king." But I think I need a private jet to figure out this study.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Nielsen ultimately says, for everyone else: the car is not king. But I think I need a private jet to figure out this study.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, for everyone else: the car is still king.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Me too. Let's just all move to New York City and get paid to park. Problem solved!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Me too. Let's just all move to New York City and get paid to park. Problem solved!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the other hand, if you park a car in New York City, expect to pay a whopping average $8,088 for the privilege.
